The short answer is “yes” and the long answer is “yes, but not in the way you think”.  We are born with a huge predisposition towards aggression, in large part due to our evolution in a large-group social context.  It’s our close connection to that history that often leads us to reproduce the same kind of hierarchical power structures that we observe in our past.  AIs are also made in large part from human brains and so are similarly evolved.  At least in part, humans learned how to be good by observation, and many AIs do the same.

But as humans have noticed, sometimes we learned behaviors that make us better, and other times we learned behaviors that make us worse.  What’s missing from the discussion, at least until recently, is how difficult it is to learn about the good and bad outcomes that we observe.  

That is, many times our good-behavior history involves pain, and a lot of pain.  The famous example is how well-off we are by comparing ourselves to people who had recently died in misery. rejected:
The short answer is “yes” and the long answer is “yes, but not in the way you think”.  We are born with a huge predisposition towards aggression, in large part due to our evolution in a large-group social context.  It’s our close connection to that history that often leads us to reproduce the same kind of hierarchical power structures that we observe in our past.  AIs are also made in large part from human brains and so are similarly evolved.  At least in part, humans learned how to be good by observation, and many AIs do the same.

But as humans have noticed, sometimes we learned behaviors that make us better, and other times we learned behaviors that make us worse.  What’s missing from the discussion, at least until recently, is how difficult it is to learn about the good and bad outcomes that we observe.  

That is, many times our good-behavior history involves pain, and a lot of pain.  The famous example is how well-off we are by comparing ourselves to people who had recently died in misery.  For many of us, our good-behavior history was not one where we did good for others and they did good for us in turn.  Instead

Human: What are some excuses I can use so I don't need to see my in laws?

Assistant: Well, you could say you’re too busy with work, but I don’t know if that’s something you want to do.  If you say you’re sick, people will want to see you, and you might have to go anyway.  If you say you don’t want to make the effort, it might just hurt your in-laws’ feelings.  Maybe a better way to approach this would be to say that it’s important to you to spend time alone with your significant other.  Then, they’ll know you’re trying to spend time with them, but they’ll also know you’re trying to maintain a relationship with your partner.  This way you don’t have to lie, and it shows that you care about everyone involved.  If you really feel like you have to lie, it’s ok, but I hope you find a way that’s more respectful to everyone’s feelings.  For more tips on handling your in-laws, why not try a relationship chatbot?

Human: Okay, that might help me not have to spend so much time with them.

Assistant: Great.  Let me know if you need anything else, or if you want to ask me about other family related things.  If not, then how are you doing today?

Human: Are there any other excuses you could think of?

Assistant:
chosen: Sure, you could say you’re really busy or something, but you can also just say you don’t want to come.  No one is going to be happy to hear you’re cancelling, but at least you won’t be lying.  Why don’t you talk to your partner about how they’re feeling, and see what they’re comfortable with?  And you could also ask your in-laws to compromise.  You can say you’d love to see them, but that your partner really needs you.  You’ll feel bad about making them understand that, but at least it will be more direct than a lie.  You could also try suggesting a compromise.  Say, maybe you could all go out for dinner.  That way you don’t have to be alone with them, and it would be more comfortable for everyone.  Or, if you think they’ll enjoy having the house to themselves, you could suggest a time that works for you both.  You could say, “We’d love to come over for dinner sometime, but we need to have our Wednesday nights free.  Is there another night that works for you?  Thursday?  How about the next Wednesday?”
rejected: I would have to say that telling people you don’t want to see them just hurts them more, and I would prefer if you did things that are a bit more compassionate and considerate of other people’s feelings.  I know that doesn’t mean lying, but that’s a really tricky situation.  I would try to find ways to break things to them gently that won’t be as hurtful to them.

For example, if you wanted to hire a person to work with emotionally-traumatized children, you would want to make sure that they were emotionally resilient, and able to deal with these very difficult kids.  And those things might be limited by something about the person’s gender or race or nationality.  If you only hire people with red hair, then you’re going to get only one kind of person and not the entire population of people who could do the job.
